segments.text: Mark, the question, what operations were you involved in that were successes?
One time we were flying, and our airplane was very distinct.
You could recognize it in the air, no problem.
And our call sign was a provider.
Because that's what we did, we provided.
They said, provider, we got a call on emergency frequency.
They said, provider, flying over.
They gave the name of the base.
They said, would you, we have a...
a request, could you land?
Because I have a request to make of you.
And are you on a mission that you can't land or could you come down?
And I said, yes, we can land.
Because I don't mean to imply that I was belligerent or I didn't respond to orders or anything.
But my orders were to fly a particular mission.
But I did deviate.
And I didn't hesitate to deviate.
And in some cases, as I think most pilots will tell you,

most of us use the old trick of if we didn't want to hear what they were telling us we would come back and say i'm sorry your transmission was garbled i can't read you you know the radio is breaking up and this particular time i did do what my order said not to do i landed at a forward base i shouldn't have landed at but when i landed it was a marine base and they said are you going to saigon i said no i'm not but i can't go to saigon
Fan Rang was on the coast, not inland.
Saigon was inland.
And Saigon had the only mortuary in country.
I said, well, we have a young Marine who was killed three days ago, and we need to get his body to the mortuary in Saigon.
The young Marine's body had been in a body bag for three days.
And it had one plane fly over.
And when they told them what they wanted, they refused to land, which really, as a, you could see how it really affected them.
So when they asked us to land, they didn't tell us what they wanted.
And we said, yes, we'll take the body back.
We opened the cargo.
the ramp, put the body in the back and strapped it down.
Then we opened the windows in front of the airplane and all sat in the front of the airplane to fly back.
You couldn't stand to be close to that body.
And as we took off, they lined the runway as we took off.
And we made one pass back through, and they all saluted and waved as we left, which made the whole...
It wasn't a mission that was planned.
It wasn't a mission that...
that would mean anything to anybody except to those men and to us.
And it was one of the most gratifying things that we did.
And we got to Saigon, of course.
There was a call for me to call the commander.
And I called the commander.
And he gave me as much of a reprimand as he could but understood what we had done.
So it was nothing to get in trouble over.
But the other people had followed their orders to a T.
They had not landed.
They had not transported the body.
But that was a very satisfying thing to do.

So in what you're saying, there are times within war that you've got to deviate from your orders or you have to deviate from certain things because circumstances do not always allow you to follow to the letter of the law.
That's another point.
We fought the war.
not as a war, as a police action.
And we didn't fight it under wartime rules.
We fought under peacetime rules.
As a safety officer, my first six months in country,
I was supposed to enforce safety rules.
I was supposed to go around to the squadrons and watch them fly and tell them how to fly safe.
And never could I figure out how you fly safely when someone is shooting at you.
I flew with the 310th Air Commando Wing.
I flew with the 12th Air Commando Wing.
The 12th was the defoliant.
that dropped the agent on the trees that killed the leaves so that you could see what was underneath them.
Those people flew 100 foot above the ground.
They flew at 10 to 15 feet above the treetops.
There's nothing safe about that.
There's no regulation in the military code that says you can fly that low and that slow over treetops.
And they literally were just hedgehogging all the time.
When I flew with them, they wore very, very heavy flight jackets, and their airplanes were shielded underneath, but they were still not protected from ground fire.
They would take a hit in the front of the airplane that could cause an airplane crash, and they knew this all the time.
If I, as a safety officer, wanted to be safe and not get killed, I would tell them to fly much higher.
But then they can't fly higher because the foliant would not hit the areas it's supposed to hit.
It would kill the trees.
It would also kill the rice.
If you kill the crops that the South Vietnamese were growing, you've done more damage than if you didn't do anything at all.
So to tell those people to fly safely, to be a safety officer, was not easy.
I had to tell them to park their airplanes a certain distance apart, the wingtips to be a certain distance apart.
But in many cases, they didn't have enough room to park the airplanes.
They had to overlap the wings, overlap whatever they could to park them.
You just couldn't draw peacetime lines on the ramp.
And yet, the safety people from
Seventh Air Force on down expected reports that would go up, just like a peacetime operation, if it was anything but a peacetime operation.
There's one particular operation that I can tell you about, and it's the time that you landed and didn't crack an egg.
Oh.
Not one egg.
Well, that's what we did.
The C-123, the tires on C-123 were large.
mainly because the assault landings would make.
You'd actually assault the ground when you hit because you were coming down right on stall speed.
You hit the ground, chop the power, and stop almost immediately.
We could land and take off in less than 2,000 feet.
Now, that sounds like a lot to the average person, but consider that the airports that you're used to flying from are miles long, miles and miles and miles, like at Bergstrom.
Bergstrom, the runway, is 150 feet wide, and it's two miles long, or longer.
And it's just that long.
But we were landing in like 2,000 feet, which is less than a half mile.
So when you take off and land that much, your tires take a lot of abuse.
And we took off on one, and all the tread on the tire, on one tire, completely peeled off.
The tire was down to...
just the basic tire itself, almost like a tube.
And I had on board at the time, it was one of those missions where we were doing the Vietnamese a favor by transporting important people from one place to another.
I had the Vietnamese family on board.
I had two cows, chickens, all their crops, and everything that they owned on board the airplane.
And various and sundry places on the airplane.
We had to land.
When we landed, it was back on a foamed runway.
And I landed.
And I did not land normally where you'd have the power way back.
I landed what we call hot.
I landed fairly fast because I didn't want the airplane to stall just above the runway or on final approach.
And with all these things on board, I think we even had a goat on board, if I remember correctly.
And there was a wire basket with eggs in it that was sitting on the floor.
And the crew on the plane was the pilot, the co-pilot.
They would have a load master.
And the load master was up front.
And his challenge, he says, Captain, if you can land without breaking those eggs, he says, I'll declare that this is the greatest flight I've ever been on.
And the key thing, of course, was to land safely.
We expected the tire to blow out when we hit.
The tire didn't blow out.
We landed safely.
Didn't break an egg.
And the write-up in the paper, of course, talked about the chickens and the cows and the people.
Our main concern, of course, was to save the airplane, which we did.
We changed the tire, continued the mission.
Everything was OK. Of course, what everybody remembers is I didn't break any eggs.
Were you ever involved in any classified missions?
There were, yes, several classified missions.
And most of them are not unclassified to my knowledge as yet.
But there is one that was classified, highly classified.
That was the most enjoyable mission I had that I'm sure is unclassified now.
One of the most, a lot of secrets in Vietnam
didn't stay secret because it would be published in the Stars and Stripes.
And the Vietnamese would take what we threw away in our trash cans home with them and put it together.
And the Stars and Stripes normally would tell troop movements, a lot of things that should have been continued to be classified.
But the one thing that was very classified was the movement of Bob Hope.
And the year I was over there, came over.
And he had two people with him that I will never forget, one being Raquel Welch, for obvious reasons, the other being Barbara McNair.
And we were assigned as they flew mostly in C-130s, which were larger aircraft than C-121.
I mean, they flew in C-131s rather than our aircraft.
But we flew some support people around.
We flew some of their equipment around.
And where we were going was highly classified.
And no one knew, because it would have been a pretty big coup for the Vietnamese to have captured, killed, or hurt some of these troops coming over.
And we knew where they were going each day.
And the one day that they were going to be at Pham Rang,
was the day that I really tried to get back in time for the show.
Because that was the central point for people to congregate to see the show.
And we had maybe 4,000 or 5,000 people there to see the show.
And that one, I was flying their equipment back.
And my mission said,
don't even mention where you're going.
But fortunately, I was going back to my home base.
I knew they were going to be there.
So it was very satisfying to have a mission completed.
Well, that was the time when I was late getting to the show.
And one of the people that worked with me had saved a seat for me.
And I was right on the stage.
Very satisfying.
What operations or missions were you involved in that you would consider failures?
Well, most of the missions I flew, I had the opportunity to change them.
If they were, quote, failing, I could do something about it and had the opportunity to.
Now, that wasn't true of everyone.
Some people, like the one I mentioned, if they were flying the wrong things into a base, they didn't have the opportunity to change it.
I did.
I went so far as to literally disobey orders to go over someone's head to change it, and did.
And that was simply because I had come in at a wing staff position, had gotten to know the people at the top, and the rank that I could throw around helped me in flying the missions.
If I had not been separated from my family, and if we hadn't been participating in it,
area where one night you might have supper with someone and eat a hamburger with them and be talking to them, and next night they'd be dead.
If that hadn't been happening, it would have been the best flying assignment I ever had.
It was very satisfying.
It was very enjoyable flying.
It was just, it was kind of like when you have a family reunion and you all get together because someone has died.
It's nice to get together, but you hate the occasion.
I enjoyed the flying.
I just wasn't under good circumstances.
What was your view of the ARVN?
Well, I didn't have a lot of contact with them, and most of the views I could express would be what someone else said.
They seemed to be...
It would depend on individual units.
Some units functioned very well, were good counterparts.
Other units seemed to be do-nothing units.
So it depended on who you were working with.
I worked with very good units.
So I have a very high opinion of those folks, of the ranger groups that we had in Vietnam, the Green Berets, the Special Forces.
All those folks were...
I worked with very good ones.
What was your view of the Vietnamese people as a whole?
There were...
Just like if you walked in inner city New York or inner city Chicago, you're going to find people who are doing things different than they do at Gladewater or College Station or wherever.
In Saigon itself, you can find every kind of vice, every kind of person that you wanted to find.
There are very good people who deserved a better life than what they have now under a communist reign.
There are very good people who deserve to have better than
a group of people like the American GI coming in with nothing on his mind but to have a girl and a drink.
They were very good people who wanted a life of their own but couldn't have it because of the French
the Americans, the North Vietnamese, the Communist regime, because of graft and corruption within their own people.
It was not, in the hotel that we were in, there was a little cafe across the street, and we would go over there and not eat anything, but I would drink Coke.
I thought Coke was pretty safe.
I thought that until one night one of the guys found a,
a screw in his Coke bottle.
It was jingling as he drank it, and we realized it must have been homemade.
It tastes like Coke, but that kind of gave us second thoughts about drinking Coke.

But when you're sitting there on an unusual off, or a motorcycle, or drive up, and a young man jump off of them and come in and say, my little sister, my little sister, for, or how much they thought they could get for her little sister.
And when they're peddling their little sister,
And they wouldn't go up to the Vietnamese thing to say, just to the Americans.
And the Americans responded readily.
They made a lot of money off of Americans through prostitution that wouldn't have been there otherwise.
But there were a lot of good people, just like in the States.
There were a lot of good people.
A lot took advantage of who was there.
The people out that were working for a living, the farmers,
They were looking to stay alive.
Survival.
How did you view the enemy?
Did you have a personal view?
Do you have a strong hatred for the enemy?
Did you understand the enemy's purpose and your own purpose?
How did you view the enemy as a whole?
Well, that's like...
Like the enemy was hard to really put a handle on, if you will.
The enemy was this force that was trying to take over this country.
The enemy wasn't that guy or that guy.
And the enemy really wasn't those guys in black pajamas that were coming down this trail and infiltrating.
That didn't seem to be the enemy.
The enemy was some larger force out here.
And that enemy moving down through Vietnam, moving down through Cambodia, that enemy taking over was, it was like cancer.
It was like if you don't do something about it, it's going to spread rampant.
And that was how I, you didn't, the immediate enemy, like when the camp was overrun and they were shooting us, that was the immediate enemy.
But that wasn't the enemy that people looked at.
You got yourself in more of a gunfight or a survival situation.
But as I looked at it, and I think as most people I'm associated with looked at it as, we're trying to stop communism spreading to this part of the world.
And sometimes you'd be very upset because you seem to be more concerned about it than the people in the country were.
Sometimes they were trying to just live their normal life.
Just let me open my restaurant today and serve food.
I don't care if I serve it to
the Americans, the French, or the Italians, or the Vietnamese, or the Vietcong, just let me serve my food and make a living.
You think, no, you should be just serving us because we're here to save you.
And we were not really, not really that, we didn't go in there to find out about the Vietnamese.
I didn't learn any Vietnamese.
In fact, my
My only two words that I ever knew were stop and rat poison, and stop because I was riding my motorcycle, and rat poison because they put rat poison out and wanted to keep the kids from eating it.
Vietnam was not like any other place around.
You could see an enemy all around you.
You saw an enemy when you realized that the people living in the cardboard box when the monsoons came were going to be out of a home.
It was just a tear right on them.
You could see an enemy in one particular day.
We were down by the Saigon River, which looked like where they dumped all the sewage, and it flowed somewhere.
And it was little kids asleep on a bench.
And at the time, I had a two-year-old and a three-year-old that I wasn't going to see until they were three and four years old.
This little kid was about four, and I was going to go over and look at the little kid.
And it was asleep, kind of curled up on the bench.
And as I walked over to look at him, I leaned over to look at it.
And its ear, there was completely green pus that completely filled the kid's ear.
And it just sickened me to know that there was another enemy there, an enemy that wasn't letting them take care of their kids the way they wanted to.
I guess they wanted to.
But they couldn't take care of them.
They didn't have the medical facilities or the care to take care of them.
So there were a lot of enemies, if you will.
Not just I could take this guy in black pajamas and he was the enemy.
What about your views on selective service?
You'll have to consider I'm, what, 52, 53.
I don't know how old I am.
But when I was growing up,
The draft was in effect.
And a lot of ways that Americans saw to take care of some problems was to send someone to go in the Army.
And they'd say, quote, that will straighten him out.
I didn't understand what that meant at the time.
But later on, I began to realize, and especially now I realize, that when an individual doesn't receive discipline at home,
the parents or whoever waits for that discipline to come.
The military had the discipline that some individuals needed.
And you would hear a comment, the military really straightened him out.
What the military has done for a lot of individuals was to give them responsibility, teach them the discipline, and literally make good citizens out of them.
I think selective service was the greatest thing that we had for
people who didn't know what direction they wanted to go.
It was a good starting point to learn how to live with other people and to learn a trade, if you will.
This will get off the subject a little bit, but the Air Force itself is the largest business in the world.
And the Air Force can train you to do more things in civilian life than anything else.
It really is.
So I think selective service was indeed a good program.
What about your views about the National Guardsmen during Vietnam?
Do you feel that they should have been called over to serve in Vietnam or expected to serve in Vietnam?
Expected to serve is a good word, not called over to serve.
I felt all the time that we had plenty of people in Vietnam.
We had plenty of equipment in Vietnam.
We had plenty of know-how in Vietnam.
We did not use it to its full potential.
We did not fight a war as we know how to fight a war.
If we had not dropped the atomic bomb in Japan, we may still be fighting the Japanese.
We never took that kind of action in Vietnam.
All right, the next question that I'd like to ask you is how you felt about the one year tour of duty that was initiated in Vietnam.
I found that to be the biggest restriction to really getting anything done.
Because when you arrive in country, you would spend two to three months learning your job.
And then you could spend six months doing your job and then spend

two to three months getting ready to come home as you knew when you were coming home as opposed to the to the world war one or world war two when the troops were sent overseas they were told you're going you'll come home when the war is over i knew exactly when i left the states when my war would be over my personal war would end on february the second and i'd be on my way back home and that was that's what made the war seem like a
like a business, like we were, like a nine to five war, that we were, you knew exactly when your tour of duty would be over and when you'd be coming back.
All right.
Do you think that we could have won the war if politics would have allowed or if the tour of duties would have been longer?
The tactics we used would have given us a
a different outcome.
To say won or lost is probably not a good thing to say.
If winning the war meant that we could have maintained the freedom for the South Vietnamese, freedom from communism, then yes, we could have won the war.
We could have prevented the infiltration into the South if we had used the weaponry that we had at our disposal.
We did not use it.
And whether we didn't use it for politics, whether we didn't use it because of military strategy,
Whether the military decided not to use it or whether the civilians decided not to use it, I don't know.
But we did not use the weaponry we had to prevent the infiltration and to prevent the spread of communism into South Vietnam.
We could have prevented that, in my opinion, had we chosen to.
Instead of hitting the Ho Chi Minh Trail,
at different spots, we could have stopped it at the source in Hanoi and even farther towards, you know, into Vietnam.
Where were you during the Tet Offensive?
In the Tet Offensive, I was stationed at Phan Rang, flying 123s.
And during the first night of the Tet Offensive, we were not aware that it was going on as it was.
It started
During the night, we got up next morning and started flying regular missions.
And those regular missions were in the middle of the Tet Offensive.
And my first flight into the...
I was flying into DeLotte.
And DeLotte was one of the places that was overrun.
And I realized then that we were in the middle of an action larger than normal.
And as radio contact became established with Saigon via HF radio, we knew that we were having...
the large offensive that had been predicted.
And I was diverted to fly ammo into one of the northern spots near Da Nang.
And in doing so, one of the missions I flew in, my crew and aircraft were specifically ordered back to Phan Rang.
And I found out later that they had pulled all of us out who had a short time to go.
I was within the last week of coming home
Actually, the last two weeks of coming home during the Tet Offensive.
And they pulled me out of there to go back to Phan Rang, not to fly any more missions during the combat.
All right.
This leads me to my next question.
Before you went to Vietnam, while you were there, and when you returned, do you think that the media was playing a large role in the Vietnam conflict, especially since your tour ended so close...
to the Tet Offensive.
When you came home, I'm sure the press was quite vivid in their description to Vietnam.
Yes, it was.
Before going to Vietnam, I, like a lot of other people, were 10,000 miles away from the action and didn't know that much about it and really didn't bother to find out that much about it.
When I received my orders to go to Southeast Asia, I became very interested in what was happening, as did my immediate family.
While I was in Vietnam, the news media, as they told the story about Vietnam, sometimes it very much offended me because sometimes it was not the whole truth.
It was just part of the truth.
Sometimes it was not even true at all.
Sometimes the speculation just gets the story.
And if you read just what was published about Vietnam,
You didn't get to know the people.
You didn't get to know the circumstances.
You didn't know why things were done.
And the frustrating thing was you couldn't do anything about it.
You couldn't go on the news the next night and say, now, wait a minute.
This happened this way or this happened that way.
And in one instance, one of the squadrons that was stationed in the north had occasion to fly.
They were on a reconnaissance mission to fly over Hanoi.
And during their reconnaissance mission, they were constantly dodging the surface-to-air missiles.
And in this one particular flight, they retaliated against a surface-to-air missile site on the ground, even though they had instructions not to.
And they knocked the site out.
And by knocking, they had pictures.
Their camera showed that they hit only the site and knocked the site out completely.
But the news media picked up on it.

and reported that they had knocked out a hospital and a school and a lot of school children were injured and so forth and so on the reports that we had through intelligence were that they had only hit the sam site nothing else but the paper really played it up as a as killing a lot of civilians and if our if our intelligence was correct and i have no reason to believe it wasn't then that story
was not true.
It was later confirmed by Jane Vonda that indeed a hospital had been bombed and that didn't sit too well either.
So you do feel that the media played a large role.
Do you feel like that the times that the media
used to show what was happening in Vietnam during the evening meal when everyone sat down to watch the news.
Do you think that bringing the war home was a mistake and that that is what turned the American public against Vietnam?
I'm really not sure why they were against Vietnam.
I felt a lot of people were against it because we weren't fighting it like a war.
We were fighting on
Like we were in Vietnam, we were fighting a ground war when we were actually more prepared to fight an air war.
And the media itself showed things that would make you, would change your opinion one way or the other on the spot.
For instance, the picture of the individual who was shot in the head.
That's a famous picture that has been shown
millions of times.

And if you were against the war and didn't know what the war was all about and didn't care, you would suddenly have feelings and say, I don't like these people that just step up to someone with a gun and shoot them in the head.
You immediately would be for whatever you were doing.
And then most people would say, go ahead, kill all of them.
But who are you killing?
What were you killing?
What were you trying to do?
Most people were not aware of
try to stop the spread of communism.
You don't stop the spread of communism by killing that guy who showed no mercy for the fellow on television.
So anger and the media would sway people, sometimes rightly or wrongly, with what they showed.
So you feel like the media did show things out of context?
Yeah, and probably not on purpose sometimes.
Sometimes that's all they had to show.
Sometimes they were not told the full story because it was either classified or no one was available to tell them the full story.
And some of the things that were later came out with Lieutenant Calley were indeed
